name: Bob Connolly
description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Bob Connolly
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film director, cinematographer and author. He is best known for his documentaries produced over the past 30 years, including The Highlands Trilogy (1983) and Rats in the Ranks (1996). More recent films include Facing the Music (2001) and Mrs Carey’s Concert (2011).

end.title: First contact
end.creator_credit: Stewart Young, Dick Smith Adventure, Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly and Arundel Productions
end.brief_description: Documents the clash of two cultures that occurred in the 1930s when the people of the highlands of New Guinea encountered the first Europeans to enter their world. One of these Australians, Michael Leahy, took a movie camera with him.

links.description: Bob Connolly started his career as a journalist for the ABC, where he met his wife and future filmmaking partner Robin Anderson. Together they made First Contact, a documentary about gold-prospecting Australians who explored the New Guinea highlands in 1930, which was nominated for an Oscar.

links.description: Thirteen years after First Contact, the duo made the award-winning Rats in the Ranks, a documentary that followed the inner workings of the Leichardt council during Mayoral elections. Incumbent Larry Hand fights for re-election while other councillors vie for his job.

end.title: Grass Roots
end.brief_description: Grass Roots is an Australian television series produced by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation between 2000 and 2003.The series is set around the fictional Arcadia Waters Council near Sydney, and was primarily a satirical look at the machinations of local government.

end.title: Utopia
end.brief_description: Set inside the offices of the “Nation Building Authority”, a newly created government organisation responsible for overseeing major infrastructure projects, Utopia explores that moment when bureaucracy and grand dreams collide.

links.description: The bureaucracy, backstabbing and petty politics of a local council are prime material for satire. Those kinds of absurdities also exist at the federal levels of government and are ridiculed in Utopia, a satire set inside the fictional Nation Building Authority department.

end.title: Frontline
end.brief_description: Frontline is an Australian comedy television series which satirised Australian television current affairs programmes and reporting. It ran for three series of 13 half-hour episodes and was broadcast on ABC TV in 1994, 1995 and 1997.

constellations_other.name: Newsreel to nightly news
constellations_other.description: For decades, newsreel companies covered the news, providing weekly stories of current events, sport, and entertainment to audiences at the cinema, and establishing the format that would be taken up by television and the nightly news.

links.description: Utopia is one of the latest satirical programs produced by Working Dog Productions, who have also made sports, variety and game shows to name a few. One of their first critically acclaimed projects was the current affairs program satire, Frontline.

constellations_other.description: Royal watchers don't need to visit palaces around the world. There are enough stories about royalty on the silver and small screen to get their fix.

constellations_other.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up
constellations_other.description: The upper echelons of society explored through colour, make-up and scandal.

links.description: In Rake, Richard Roxburgh plays the… well, rakish criminal defence attorney Cleaver Greene, in one of the most iconic performances of the actor’s career. Another is as former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who he starred as in the TV miniseries Hawke, and later reprised in The Crown.
